Pd0-PyPPh2@porous organic polymer: Efficient heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one without extra oxidants and hydrogen acceptors Xingkun Chen a b Wenlong Wang b Hejun Zhu b ⁎ Wenshao Yang a Yunjie Ding a b c ⁎ a Hangzhou Institute of Advanced studies, Zhejiang Normal Universtity, 1108 Gengwen Road, Hangzhou 311231, PR China Hangzhou Institute of Advanced studies Zhejiang Normal Universtity 1108 Gengwen Road Hangzhou 311231 PR China b Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, PR China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 PR China c The State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, PR China The State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, PR China. Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 PR China Graphical abstract In this study, we reported an efficient heterogeneous nanocatalyst Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one without using extra hydrogen acceptors and inorganic base additives. In this contribution, we have developed an efficient and recyclable porous organic polymer (POP) supported Pd nanoparticle catalyst (Pd°-PyPPh2@POP) for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one. This heterogeneous catalytic system represents a totally clean process without using any extra oxidant and hydrogen acceptors. The SEM-EDS mapping images of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst reveal the highly uniformly dispersed character of C, Pd, P and N elements. The coordination bonds between Pd nanoparticle and exposed P atom as well as N atom on the surface of PyPPh2@POP polymer are confirmed by means of solid-state 31P NMR and XPS. Importantly, both P atom and pyridyl ring on the PyPPh2@POP polymer are themselves used as solid base over the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst, leading to a catalytic conversion of 88.2% even without the employment of inorganic base additives (K2CO3). Our results have provided a strategy for designing highly active bifunctional POP supported nanoparticle catalysts. Keywords Porous organic polymer Palladium Nanoparticle Dehydrogenation Phenol 1 Introduction Phenols and its derivatives are important precursors and core structures of useful chemical molecules in the field of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and polymers et al [1,2]. The introduction of functional groups in meta-position of phenolic hydroxyl group still remains a key challenge in the preparation of these molecules due to the strong electronic directing effect of −OH group which cause ortho- and para- substituent easier [3–6]. Thus, intensive efforts have been devoted to achieve a facile route to substituted phenols. Recently, palladium-catalyzed aerobic dehydrogenation of cyclohexenes is emerging as a versatile strategy to achieve this goal. Stahl and co-workers develop an efficient Pd/Py-based homogeneous catalytic system to dehydrogenate cyclohexanone to phenols by using molecular oxygen (Scheme 1 a) [7–15]. However, oxidative dehydrogenations for the synthesis of phenols are frequently hindered by over-oxidation due to the inherent nature of susceptible to oxidation of phenols [16]. In addition, the homogeneous nature of this system limits the catalyst recycling process [17,18]. To solve the catalyst recycling problem and realize the sustainable green catalysis, immobilization of metal complex onto insoluble supports, such as polymers, silica method in commercial exploitation [19–24]. Thus, Liu et al. report AC (activated carbon) supported palladium catalyst (Pd°@AC) for dehydrogenation of cyclohexanone to phenol in the context of oxidant- and hydrogen-acceptor-free conditions (Scheme 1b) [25]. Nonetheless, in such a catalytic system, large amount of additional K2CO3 need to be added to achieve high activities, which will cause metal contamination of the products and pollutions to the environment [26]. Porous organic polymers (POP) are one of the promising supports because of their large surface area, advanced porous structure, low skeleton density, flexible synthetic strategy, ready functionality and high stability [27–35]. Intense and continuous efforts have led to the rapid development of various POP with useful structures and properties, but there is still a persistent requirement for the design and synthesis of POP containing specific functional groups to improve their performance in heterogeneous catalysis. The incorporation of coordination groups is regarded as an efficient method to stabilize nanoparticles (NPS) [36–45]. Many monodentate and bidentate nitrogen-containing POP supported nanoparticles are employed for heterogeneous catalysis but supported nanoparticles catalyst by using POP containing both of nitrogen and phosphine coordination sites has not yet been reported [46,47]. Recently, we report a novel two-fold cross-linked porous organic polymer PyPPh2@POP, which is synthesized through polymerization of vinyl-functionalized diphenyl-2-pyridylphosphine (2- PyPPh2 ligand) containing both P and N [48]. Herein, we report PyPPh2@POP supported palladium nanoparticle catalyst (Pd°-PyPPh2@POP, Scheme 2 ) for oxidant- and hydrogen acceptor-free dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one to 3-methyl phenol. This novel heterogeneous nanocatalyst exhibits relatively high activities even without additional K2CO3. From the viewpoint of efficiency and green chemical process, the heterogeneous POP supported nanocatalyst combines excellent reactivity and eliminated pollutions as well as easy product separation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All reagents are of analytical grade and used as purchased without further purification unless otherwise stated. Tetrahydrofuran (THF) is distilled from sodium and pyridine is distilled from calcium hydride under argon. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All operations are carried out under argon conditions. PyPPh2@POP is synthesized according to our previously report (Scheme 2). The porous organic polymer support with smaller surface area which is denoted as PyPPh2@POPs is synthesized by changing the amount of AIBN and solvent during the solvothermal producing process. The procedure for preparing Pd°-PyPPh2@POP is as follows. In a typical run, 0.16 g PyPPh2@POP is added into a solution of 0.0143 g PdCl2 in 6 ml acetonitrile. After stirring 2 h at room temperature, the mixture is dried under reduced pressure at 65 °C to give a brown solid. The sample is denoted as PdCl2-PyPPh2@POP. And then it is reduced in a stream of H2 (100 ml/min) at the temperature of 300 °C (heating rate: 9 °C /min) for 5 h. In addition, the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst could also be prepared by using Pd(OAc)2. The porous organic polymer supported catalyst with smaller surface area is denoted as Pd°-PyPPh2@POPs. Pd°@AC and Pd°@Al2O3 catalysts are prepared by the same procedure. 2.3 Characterization Nitrogen sorption isotherms are measured using an AutoSorb-1 instrument. The Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is outgassed for 24 h at 120 °C before measurements. SEM and SEM-EDS mapping study is performed on a JSM-7800 F scanning electron microscope. The thermal stability of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP is detected in N2 flow (20 ml min−1) using a Diamond TG/DTA instrument, with a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1 up to 1000 °C. Solid-state 31P NMR experiments are carried out on an Infinity plus 400 spectrometer operating at 161 MHz. 13C MAS NMR spectra are recorded under a magic angle spinning rate of 6 KHz. XPS spectra are carried out on a ESCALAB 250Xi Alα radiation. TEM study is performed on a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscopy. 2.4 Catalytic performance testing In a typical run, 25 ml flask is charged with 0.016 g Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst, 0.90 g 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one and then the reactor is sealed. After replaced 5 times with argon, the contents are heated to 140 °C and stirred for 12 h. Then the reactor is cooled to room temperature with ice-water, the liquid samples are centrifuged to isolate the catalyst. And then the solution is analysed offline by Agilent 7890 A gas chromatography with a HP-5 capillary column and FID detector using isopropanol as an internal standard. Pd°@AC and Pd°@Al2O3 are used in the reaction according to the same procedure described above for the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst. 2.5 Hot filtration test The reaction is carried out in the presence of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst in 1 h and at that point the solid insoluble catalyst is filtered off at the reaction temperature. The resulting liquid filtration is placed under the same conditions as the original reaction for another 1.5 h and also analysed by GC. 2.6 Catalyst reusing test After being charged with Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst, 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one and DMA, the reactor is sealed. After replaced 5 times with argon, the contents are heated to 140 °C and stirred for 5 h. Then the reactor is cooled to room temperature with ice-water, the liquid samples are centrifuged to isolate the catalyst. And then the solution is analysed offline by Agilent 7890 A gas chromatography with a HP-5 capillary column and FID detector using isopropanol as an internal standard. The isolated catalyst is used in the reaction according to the same procedure described above for next run. 3 Results and discussion The Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is thoroughly characterized by various characterization techniques. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP and PyPPh2@POP are shown in Fig. 1 A. The obvious hysteresis loops suggest the coexistence of micro- and mesopores in the framework. The pore size distribution curves calculated by nonlocal density functional theory method (NLDFT) are displayed in Fig. 1B, which further confirm the hierarchical structures of these materials, and the hierarchical porous structure facilitates the mass transfer process. The BET surface area and pore volume of the catalyst (reduced at 300 °C) are 311 m2  g−1 and 0.49 cm3 g−1, respectively. The relatively high surface area and large pore volume of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst play a significant role in enhancing the reaction rates. 13C magic angle spinning (MAS) spectra are used to characterize the PyPPh2@POP polymer (Fig. 1C). The signal at around 32.2 ppm is attributed to the CH2 group directly linked to the aromatic ring, and the peaks at around 20 ppm are ascribed to the “−CH2CH2-” linker. It implies that the structure of the 2-vinyl-functional diphenyl-2-pyridylphosphine monomer is not destroyed during the polymerization process. Solid state 31P NMR spectrum of PyPPh2@POP (Fig. 1D) shows just one signal at -4.6 ppm, which is at the same position of the ligand monomer. Remarkably, for Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst, a new peak at 21.0 ppm appears, which is attributed to P atoms coordinated to Pd nanoparticles. It indicates that an interaction between palladium actives and the PyPPh2@POP support is present on the heterogeneous Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst. This interaction is very favourable for stabilizing palladium nanoparticles during the dehydrogenation reaction process. Thermogravimetry (TG) analysis demonstrates that the weight loss of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP starts over 330 °C, which indicates that the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is thermally stable (Fig. S1). Representative scanning electron microscope image (SEM, Fig. 2 A) of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP further confirms the rough surfaces and the existence of hierarchical porosities. Transmission electron micrograph (TEM, Fig. 2B) shows that Pd nanoparticles are uniformly distributed in polymer support and the average size of Pd nanoparticles increases from 1.81 nm to 3.40 nm (Fig. S3-8). TEM images of the used Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst reveal the stablization of palladium nanoparticles during the reaction process (Fig.5). Element distribution in the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is determined by the scanning electron microscopy-energy-disperse X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS mapping).The image reveals the highly dispersed character of all functional elements (C, Pd, P and N), which are well integrated in the catalyst (Fig. 3 ). This kind of integration in the polymer creates a very favourable coordinative condition for stabilizing palladium nanoparticle, which plays a significant role in enhancing the activity of the catalyst. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS) spectra of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP also reveal the valence state of functional elements (Fig. 4 ). The C1 s peaks (Fig. 4B) distribute near 284.6, 285.3 and 287.5 eV are assigned to CC, C–P and C–N bonds, respectively. The two peaks at 132.7 and 131.4 eV are assigned to 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 for P species, respectively (Fig. 4C). The N1 s regions of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP are deconvoluted into two peaks (399.0 and 400.7 eV), indicating the presence of two nitrogen species (Fig. 4D). This confirms that a coordination interaction of Pd and the pyridine sites is present on the PyPPh2@POP catalyst [45]. In addition, two peaks at 340.9 eV and 335.8 eV for Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst are assigned to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 for Pd° species (Fig.4E), while the other two peaks at 343.0 and 337.8 eV for PdCl2-PyPPh2@POP catalyst are assigned to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 for Pd2+ species (Fig. 4F), respectively. This confirms that the Pd(II) species are completely reduced into Pd(0) in Pd° -PyPPh2@POP catalyst. The surface compositions of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst which are detected by XPS are shown in Table S1 Entry1. By comparison of the XPS results of the relative percentage of Pd on the surface in Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst with the theoretical values, the Pd percentage decreases from 0.61 mol% (Table S1 Entry 2) to 0.4 mol% (Table S1 Entry 1), which implies that some palladium atoms are buried inside the tunnel of PyPPh2@POP support. In order to explore prospects for the proposed oxidant- and hydrogen-acceptor-free palladium nanoparticles catalyzed dehydrogenation methods, our study is initiated through investigating 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one over Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst under various conditions. In the beginning, the dehydrogenation reaction proceeds slowly to afford phenol with conversion of only 14.8% (Table1 , Entry 1). A satisfactory activity is got after 10 mol% of K2CO3 is added during the reaction process. The effects of solvents are also evaluated, and it is interesting to find that the solvent is unfavorable for the reaction (Table 1, Entry 4). This may be due to the fact that the solvent could be coordinated with Pd center and thus suppress the coordination with the reactant molecular. Stahl et al. claims that the generated hydrogen during the reaction process can be removed by oxygen and thus accelerating the reaction rate. Therefore, control experiments are performed using O2 instead of Ar. The results show that the use of O2 as gas atmosphere leads to an improvement in the selectivity of 3-methyl phenol (from 48.3% to 75.9%, Table 1, Entry 5), however, a drastically decrease in the conversion from 98.3% to 1.9% is also observed. After screening the gas atmosphere conditions, we find that inert gases (Ar and CO2) are favorable for achieving high activities (Table Entries 3 and 6). Table 2 presents the reaction performance for the dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one over various catalysts. To improve the efficiency of this Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst for dehydrogenation, various Pd loading and reducing temperature are screened in detail. The increasing of Pd loading from 0.022 mmol g−1 to 0.5 mmol g−1 led to the improvement of conversion of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one from 0% to 98.5% (Table 2, Entries 1–5). Additionally, the catalytic activity increases drastically when the reducing temperature increases from 150 to 300 °C (Table 2, Entries 2 and 3). This result might be explained by the changes of the particle size of palladium (Fig. S3-S8). The average size of Pd NPS increases from 1.81 nm to 3.40 nm with Pd loading ranging from 0.125 mmol g−1 to 0.75 mmol g−1. And higher reducing temperature leads to the increasing of Pd NPs, according to Fig. S8. In a control experiment, we carry out the reaction without K2CO3. Pd°-PyPPh2@POP which is reduced at 150 °C gives a conversion of only 17.4% (Table 2 Entry 6) when K2CO3 is not added in this reaction system. The Pd°-PyPPh2@POPs catalyst with surface area of no more than 200 m2 g−1 exhibits much lower activity (Table 2 Entry 7). However, it is observed that the reaction works better when Pd°-PyPPh2@POP is reduced at 300 °C (a good conversion of 88.2% is obtained). Furthermore, when traditional inorganic material supported palladium catalyst are used as catalyst instead of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP, the conversion is less than 30% (Table 2, Entries 8, 9, 11 and 12). And the previously reported Pd°@AC catalyst gave a relatively high conversion of 26.9% when it was reduced at 300 °C. The relatively good performance of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP in dehydrogenation reaction could be attributed to the following reasons: 1) The palladium nanoparticles are uniformly distributed in Pd°-PyPPh2@POP according to TEM images because of that the P and N functional atoms on the surface of polymer can effectively stabilize the Pd nanoparticles through the coordination effect with Pd-P and Pd-N bonds, and thus prevent the aggregation of Pd nanoparticles. Moreover, palladium nanoparticles in the interior cavities can be restricted to a proper size by the confinement effect of the pores in POP. 2) Both P atom [49] and pyridyl ring in PyPPh2@POP can act as a solid base which play an important role in accelerating reaction rates, the N atom of the pyridyl ring works as an acceptor of the H atom, thus favouring the dehydrogenation process. 3) The relatively high surface area and large pore volume of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP make the substrate easy to access the active Pd species. In addition, the optimized Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst (Table 2. Entry 10) also proves to be effective in dehydrogenation of several other ketone and quinone to the corresponding phenol derivatives (Table 3 ). Varying the substituent on the ketone and quinone do have some effect on outcome of the reaction. To our delight, both ketone and no substituted quinone are dehydrogenated with good activities. However, relatively lower activity is obtained in the case of quinone with bluky substitutes. This may be attributed to the steric hindrance of bulky substitutes which restricts the hydrogen atom transferring process. The reusability of the catalyst is also investigated. Dimethylacetamide (DMA) is used as solvent to facilitate the recycling process though it will lead to a decrease of catalytic activity. After completion of the reaction (5 h), the catalyst is separated by centrifugation and then reused for next round of reaction. In the 3rd run, a conversion of 49.8% is obtained with the reused catalyst, which parallels to the result of the first recycle of 43.7%. SEM images reveal that the porous structure of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst after 3 cycles is not changed, although the polymer has swelled in the organic solvent (Fig. S9). In addition, TEM analysis of the recovered catalyst after the third cycle shows that there is hardly any change in palladium nanoparticle size of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst (Fig. 5 ). The valence state of Pd element in Pd°-PyPPh2@POP after catalytic cycles is investigated by XPS. Remarkably, The binding energy of Pd(0) (341.9 and 336.8 eV) on the used Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is higher than the fresh catalyst Pd(0) (340.9 and 335.8 eV) probably because of the formation of H–Pd species [50] which are considered as one of the active species of the reaction (Fig. S2) [25]. Pd leaching of the heterogeneous Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst in reaction solution is detected by ICP-OES. It is found that the amount of Pd in the first reaction solution is too low to be detected, confirming that leaching is negligible. To ensure the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic process, the hot filtration test is carried out when the insoluble Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is removed from the hot reaction mixture by filtration, the reaction stops. It indicates that the catalyst is heterogeneous in nature. 31P NMR and XPS experiments results reveal that there is a strong interaction between Pd and PyPPh2@POP support. The reaction mechanism of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one is proposed, as shown in Scheme 3 , which is similar to that of Liu’s report [25]. The dehydrogenation reaction starts with a keto-enol tautomerism equilibrium process in the presence of solid pyridyl ring which acts as a solid base. The Pd-H2-PyPPh2@POP species (A) are formed when the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst is treated with H2. Then the β-position of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one is dehydrogenated to give the intermediate (B) together with the Pd-H2-PyPPh2@POP species (A). The intermediate (B) is subsequently changed into the important intermediate (C), and H2 is released due to that the N atom of the pyridyl ring plays a key role in accelerating H atoms transfer [48]. After that, the intermediate (C) is dissociated to generate the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst and the intermediate (D). Considering that the 3-methyl-cyclohexanone is detected in the reaction mixture, a hydrogenation process is also presented in Scheme 3, which is similar to the dehydrogenation process except that it proceeds in the opposite direction. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed an efficient and reusable porous organic polymer supported palladium nanoparticle (Pd°-PyPPh2@POP) catalyst featuring dual coordination sites (P and N species) for the dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one without any extra oxidants and hydrogen acceptors. The present study reveals that the use of Pd°-PyPPh2@POP instead of traditional inorganic material supported palladium catalysts (Pd°@AC and Pd°@Al2O3) significantly increases the reaction rate. Moreover, because of P atom and pridyl ring in PyPPh2@POP which acted as solid base, the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst still exhibits high activity without adding any inorganic bases (such as K2CO3). coredata.dc:description: In this contribution, we have developed an efficient and recyclable porous organic polymer (POP) supported Pd nanoparticle catalyst (Pd°-PyPPh2@POP) for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one. This heterogeneous catalytic system represents a totally clean process without using any extra oxidant and hydrogen acceptors. The SEM-EDS mapping images of the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst reveal the highly uniformly dispersed character of C, Pd, P and N elements. The coordination bonds between Pd nanoparticle and exposed P atom as well as N atom on the surface of PyPPh2@POP polymer are confirmed by means of solid-state 31P NMR and XPS. Importantly, both P atom and pyridyl ring on the PyPPh2@POP polymer are themselves used as solid base over the Pd°-PyPPh2@POP catalyst, leading to a catalytic conversion of 88.2% even without the employment of inorganic base additives (K2CO3). Our results have provided a strategy for designing highly active bifunctional POP supported nanoparticle catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Pd0-PyPPh2@porous organic polymer: Efficient heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst for dehydrogenation of 3-methyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one without extra oxidants and hydrogen acceptors
